abstract.p: Syndey uses soldiers to help transport some of 114,000 people who are attending opening ceremonies of 2000 Summer Games (S)

block.p: Sydney used soldiers to help transport some of the 114,000 people who attended the Olympic Games opening ceremony Friday.

Most spectators arrived and left without problems in the first real test of Summer Games logistics in this sprawling city of 4 million. Trains handled 90,000 people Friday night and buses carried 24,000 more. Officials said most lines were cleared within 90 minutes of the ceremony's 11:30 p.m. close.
Sydney used soldiers to help transport some of the 114,000 people who attended the Olympic Games opening ceremony Friday.

Most spectators arrived and left without problems in the first real test of Summer Games logistics in this sprawling city of 4 million. Trains handled 90,000 people Friday night and buses carried 24,000 more. Officials said most lines were cleared within 90 minutes of the ceremony's 11:30 p.m. close.

After a week of bureaucratic and political bickering about wayward bus service, the 3,500-vehicle fleet was on schedule. The drivers included about 20 members of the army, part of a group of 100 that has been posted to Olympic duty because experienced civilian drivers have been scarce.
Also at the wheel were 100 drivers from rural outposts who had quit their new behind-the-wheel jobs last week but were lured back with pay bonuses.
For the most part, the four-hour opening pageant had a military precision, from a 2,000-strong marching band to 8,000 other entertainers who hit their marks and cues.

But over all, the big show ran an hour late because the 200 national squads paraded slowly. Only the V.I.P.'s, including Bill Gates, who waved a paper United States flag, Muhammad Ali and Princess Anne were allowed automobile rides to the 110,000-seat Olympic Stadium. Minimal parking and anti-pollution policies limit the number of cars there.
